concept-wr.title: Titanium Server in a Multi-Region Environment
concept-wr.shortdesc: Titanium Server can be deployed in a multi-region configuration as the Primary Region or a Secondary Region, or both.

conbody.p: Planning topic now re-used in Sys Eng Guidelines. Craig's suggested changes and additions for Sys Eng are noted in draft comments.A region is a discrete OpenStack environment with dedicated API endpoints that typically shares at least the Identity/Keystone service with other regions. Region configurations provide for the scalability of Titanium Server clouds and inter-working with non-Titanium Server clouds.
Titanium Server offers flexible deployment in a regions configuration. Deployment options include:

li.p: Titanium Server as Primary and Secondary Region
Third-party OpenStack Cloud as Primary Region and Titanium Server as Secondary Region

conbody.p: For information about other supported multi-region configurations, including both additional shared services and multi-region configurations with non-Titanium-Server OpenStack clouds, refer to Titanium Server for Regions. Craig adds for SE Guidelines:For multi-region dimensioning and system engineering, consult Wind River personnel for your use cases.

section.title: Titanium Server as Primary and Secondary Region
section.p: This configuration provides for scalability. It enables you to scale the number of overall compute nodes to more than that supported by a single Titanium Server region, with some level of integration (through shared services) across all regions,Craig adds: and with separate Nova and Neutron domains for each region.

As shown in , selected controller services are shared between regions. Shared central services provide multi-region-wide management capabilities. Craig suggests as figure title, "Titanium Server Scalability Example with Titanium Server Primary and Secondary Regions"
